awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Aerosols, Nitrogen Oxides, and Ozone at the Mt. Bachelor Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the continuation of atmospheric measurements at Mt. Bachelor Observatory (MBO) in Central Oregon.  The MBO is a high elevation (2.8 km above sea level) observatory that has been utilized for atmospheric chemistry research for the past 15 years.  This project will build on the extensive knowledge base of past observations from MBO to examine key controls on western U.S. air quality in the spring, when natural and international anthropogenic sources of O3 and aerosols dominate, and summer, when wildfire smoke is a major driver of regional air pollution. 

Continuous measurements will be made at MBO of O3, CO, CO2, aerosol mass, scattering and absorption coefficients and meteorology.  Three specific hypotheses will be addressed in this research: (1) Daily variations in baseline O3 are driven by large scale dynamics and transport including the El Nino-Southern Oscillation, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and the changing climate. The variations in O3 that can be observed in data from both MBO and the TEMPO satellite and are important for downwind air quality in the western U.S.  (2) Nitrogen oxide chemistry in biomass burning plumes is controlled by both initial emissions and chemical processing enroute.  Production of nitrous acid from aerosol nitrates (organic and inorganic) is an important NOx recycling mechanism and a source of hydroxyl radical.  (3) Aerosol properties depend on chemical composition and aging. Light absorption by brown carbon can be comparable or exceed absorption by black carbon and can be linked to specific chemical components or chromophores. Organic aerosol volatility decreases with aging and oxidation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This sub-award was focused on expanding the broader impacts of the core award. We created and field-tested a curriculum unit designed for use in high school physical science classrooms. the curriculum makes complicated concepts and processes accessible to teachers and students and positions students as sense-makers in the process rather than as receivers of information.  Atmospheric chemistry and related processes are rarely taught in K-12 schools and teachers often struggle with how and in which contexts to teach the related NGSS performance expectations. This curriculum is a roadmap for teachers without much direct knowledge of these processes to lead high school students through observations of phenomena and analysis of authentic data. Students will develop discrete knowledge of specific atmospheric science concepts and processes. Perhaps more importantly, students will develop a better understanding of systemic interactions between biological and physical Earth systems as well as the impact that human activity has on these systems. The curriculum is contextualized in phenomena related to wildfire smoke, something more and more students around the US are directly impacted by.  This approach builds relevance and a desire to know more about the phenomena while also allowing students to connect it to their own lived experience.  The curriculum will be shared in a forthcoming publication.
